Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of a Decision Aid to Improve Access to Total Knee Replacement Surgery for Black Patients with Osteoarthritis

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a 40-minute decision aid video on TKR or usual care.

Participants.evidence: 336 black participants aged 50 years or older with chronic knee pain, a Western Ontario McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index score of at least 39, and radiographic evidence of knee OA were recruited from three medical centers

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either a 40-minute decision aid video on TKR or usual care.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether a decision aid improves access to TKR for black patients with OA of the knee.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was receipt of TKR within 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 168 participants were randomised to each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the intention-to-treat analysis, 25 intervention patients (14.9%) and 13 controls (7.7%) underwent TKR within 12 months
